LUCE PRESS CLIPPINGS
Women seeking a more 'integrated life,' poll says
By BETH GARDINER Associated Press
NEW YORK - A majority of women say combining career, mar- riage and children is the best recipe for a satisfying life, but the strains of balancing all three elements may actually be making working moth- ers unhappy, according to a poll released Wednesday.
Researchers found 64 percent of mothers with jobs believe having a career and family is the most fulfilling path. But only 40 percent of married women with children and full-time jobs said they were very satisfied with their lives, com- pared to 59 percent of women with children but no jobs and 56 percent of mothers who work part-time.
The findings were reported in the Virginia Slims Opinion Poll of women.
"Increasingly. women are looking for an integrated life, and with the increasing number of hours that everyone is spending ac work ... that is becoming harder and harder," said Camlyn Setlow; an executive de Roper Scorch Wirktwile, which conducted che
poll of 2,177. women and 826 men. It has a margin of error of plus or minus 3 to 4 percentage points.
Although 84 percent of working mothers said they feel confident about their ability to juggle work and family, 87 percent said there was too much pressure for women trying to balance such responsibil- ities and 66 percent said conflict- ing demands produced a lot of stress.
Forty-three percent said they have trouble giving work their full attention. Setlow said the majority of women said that the most important thing to them was being independent. Despite the stresses, 35 percent of working mothers said they consider their johs a source of great personal satisfaction, and 72 percent said their joh means more to thent than just money. Only 34 percent said they would not work if they did not have to,
Forty-five percent of working men polled said their job makes it harder to do things for their family, and #1 percent sall they feel guilty about noe spending more time with family.

poll of 2,177. women and 826 men. It has a margin of error of plus or minus 3 to 4 percentage points.

Although 84 percent of working mothers said they feel confident about their ability to juggle work and family, 87 percent said there was too much pressure for women trying to balance such responsibil- ities and 66 percent said conflict- ing demands produced a lot of stress.
